(Wrapping the cabanas up in tarps like a 100 degree present does not allow for any air flow. Every time I sat in there for more than 20 minutes I would get light headed). We also were not informed that the money we paid for the cabanas was a credit towards food. Boyfriend and I were eating leftover buffalo wings in the room when his mother calls us and informs us we have a thousand dollars that needs to be spent in only a few hours.

What was even more frustrating is we had ordered some drinks in the cabana and the waitress had brought us a bill to room charge it. Wth? If we have a thousand dollars of credit why did you not just deduct it? Jeez lady.

Our phone also did not work in the room, which we discovered when we wanted room service at 330 AM. Glad you have 24 hour room service, but if I cannot call it then what good does that do? I went to look up the front desk phone number so I could call on my cell phone and there is not a phone number listed on the web site. Only an 800 number to make reservations. Fail. 

Vegas was nice though! This part just could use a ton of improvment.

I am at Rio in vegas, the place is pretty empty but the buffet is pretty good.
I dont know what gonna happen to this place, it seems pretty dated and going out of business.
The price was reasonable for all you can eat $27
I recommend this place.

We planned out last night in Vegas doing the VooDoo Zip line for our 3 High School graduates and then Buffet.  Our party of eight was highly disappointed to find out that the VooDoo zip line and Lounge decided to open at 7pm instead of 7:30pm as the website indicates for anyone under 21 so our 715pm reservation on the VooDoo was cancelled with no consideration of our time, money, or expectation.  Highly disappointed with this experience and we won't recommend the 3rd Party Vendor, Rio, and Total Rewards because the hotel has no response or assistance to the lack of communication from their contracted vendor and don't care to make it right.  Way to end out 6 day trip for our party of 8 that spend hundreds of dollars at the Flamingo Steak Restaurant last night another Total Rewards location.  The Rio was unable to compensate anything even for our buffet because they can't do anything about their 3rd Party Vendor VooDoo.  Thanks Total Rewards and Rio Hotel and Casino for nothing.

12 months later, and the Rio flatly denied any responsibility for my illness, and subsequent hospital visit that I still owe $1000 on. It's disgusting that they all but called me a liar.  Their own security wheeled me to a waiting to car, throwing up the entire way. I was nowhere else in Las Vegas my entire trip, and did not eat outside the hotel even once.

Sad, because we had made the Rio our Christmas family getaway for the last two years. As the season approaches, we aren't making reservations at The Rio.

Shame on you guys.

Samba Rooms Rule!

We were staying at the Rio for a week with a comped standard room, and after reading some of the reviews I was a little apprehensive about staying here...to the point that we reserved a room in another hotel for later in the week, in case things went sour. In the end, it was a very pleasant and enjoyable stay at the Rio!

We arrived near midnight and didn't have long to wait to check-in. Instead of the standard room we upgraded ourselves to one of the newly renovated Samba rooms in the Masqueraded tower. The room was very nice and very big. Two double beds, a couch, a safe, a minibar and a separate fridge (that came in very handy) and there's a window in the shower...it that looks onto the sleeping and sitting area...curious location for a window.

Anyways, we did stay for the whole week and cancelled the other hotel plans. The casino itself was fine and didn't reek of cigarette smoke. I found all staff members, regardless of their position to be very friendly and courteous. The cocktail waitress were lovely and came by frequently asking if we needed any beverages.


Pros
fast elevators to our floor.
hot, hot water for the shower and bath.
the shower head was an energy saver shower head, but it was still powerful.


Cons
our room had adjoining room via a locked door...very noisy when someone in the next room is standing near the adjoining door and talking.
noisy hallway...you will be wakened from your sleep with people talking in the hallway...glad I brought earplugs....although Ive experience this noise in other Vegas hotels.
if your a light sleeper you might hear highway traffic and railway train noise if your room faces the strip.
the TV is a nice modern Panasonic, but the signal to the TV in non high-definition and the setting on the TV has the images stretched from their original 4\/3 image to a 16\/9 image which could not be changed.
met other guests in the elevator, on two separate occasions, they were very unhappy with there rooms and were on their way to talk to the front desk.
Kleenex and toilet tissue are institutional quality.
The vending machine on our floor was charging $5 for a soft drink...really!?



Tips
walk over to the Gold Coast Hotel for inexpensive liquor and beer, but first sign up for a loyalty card at the Gold Coast and get 10% off you liquor and beer!
walk over to the Gold Coast to gamble, but beware, the cigarette smoke will sting your eyes!
cut through the Gold Coast and head over to the Palms Casino to gamble...it has a decent food court and an movie theatre too.
there's a small grocery store, Green Valley Grocery, located at the intersection of S Valley View Blvd and Twain Ave...its a 10 minute walk if you want to grab some snacks, juice, bottled water, milk, etc...but do not go there on foot after dark...I noticed few undesirables lurking about...there's also a Chevron, another 10 min walk at E Flamingo\/S Arville St.
find the Burger King in the Casino and grab some free WIFI, and the two Starbucks might have free WIFI?
Take the shuttle to Bally's or the other shuttle to Harrah's...the shuttles leave every 30 minutes from 10 to 1 pm.

Be aware of the up sell upon check in.  I had booked my rooms to celebrate my sons 21st birthday through hotels.com.  When I checked in was offered a room upgrade.  I was told it would be $30 more per night.  Although I was a bit reluctant because the hotel.com reservation did not include the exorbitant resort fees.  I was excited and agreed.  I was given papers to sign and questioned the final charge but was told, "no worries it will be reflected correctly upon checkout".  When I checked out I was flabbergasted the upgrade was actually the full rate per night on top of what I paid hotels.com.  When I questioned these charges I was given a very robotic sales pitch and the statement you can read the agreement you signed several times.  What I was told was a supervisor came out and reiterated the same.  The worst part is that same room was advertised on hotel.com for less then what I was up charged.  Well, shame on me and shame on them.  It will be the last time I patronage the Rio or any other Caesars\/Harrah's property again.  Buyer beware!

Great place. Room was on the 19th floor with my boyfriend. However the only complaint was going from the parking lot up to the room, a small journey. But not too bad. Other than that the view of the strip was SPECTACULAR, and room service was great too.

We've stayed at the Rio many times over the last 15+ years, and although the rooms are showing their age it is still a decent place to stay - if you get a good rate. 

Pros.
- Check-in took less than 10 minutes, and the front desk staff was friendly.
- Our room was spacious, with a table & 2 chairs, sofa and 1 lounge chair with ottoman. 
- Amenities included a safe and a refrigerator
- Room was clean.
- Free shuttle to several locations on the strip.

Cons.
- A lot of the furniture's wood was nicked.
- Some of the carpet seams were showing.
- Pillows were very uncomfortable. 
- Keurig Coffee is in the mini-bar and $8 for 3 cups! 
- $ 22 + Tax Resort fee covered Internet for one device, fitness center access for two people per day and all local calls. Yeah I know resort fees are ubiquitous, but I still don't like them - and as our room was comped, I think they should have been waived.

- Casino. The Rio used to be such a fun place when the masquerade shows were running, but now it's lost a lot its original appeal. While it has been renovated, we don't care for the selection or layout, so we usually spend our time across the street at the Gold Coast which has a much better selection of games, especially video poker.

Food. Like most Harrah's properties, the food is pricey. We thought the Pho Da Nang Vietnamese Kitchen had overpriced, mediocre food (unacceptable being located across the street from Ping Pang Pong), the Sports Deli was so-so. The BK Whopper Bar has $9 burgers (Guess "Whopper" refers to the price).
Terrible service,poor staff would give zero stars if I could.People would cut into lines while everyone else have been waiting,very short on staff 8 unused computers.

1 star for great price and large rooms.

Let's start with customer service. I checked in along with friends for a Bachelorette Party. My friend who has a disability, asked for handicap accessible check in because the line was too long and he was in pain. The lady literally looked him up and down and said "You're disabled? You look fine to me." Wow. Unbelievably disrespectful. Then when unasked for early check in, I was charged. Now I get that's policy, but we were spending 3 grand in this hotel for one night. We had 3 rooms, 8 tickets to Chippendales and bottle service at Voodoo. C'mon guys, comp the fee. 

The first room had outdated furniture that was literally falling apart. All the lamps were falling over and the desk was tilted. I was scared to put anything heavy on it. The second room had guests inside wheb we went in. Awkward. So they changed rooms to one that seemed overpowering of smoke, even though it was supposed to be a non-smoking room. The hotel staff said it was mesquite? Umm what? The third room was promised strip view and instead had a view of nothing. Not even the pool. The lady even promised a view of the Bellagio water show which I'm not convinced you can see from any Rio rooms, but definitely not from this one.

The bathroom sink made a loud noise every time you turned the water off and the shower was HORRIBLE. The shower head only halfway worked and the rest of the water was still coming out of the faucet. It's completely dark inside the shower because there's no extra light and a dark shower curtain. 

The toiletries provided were a bar of soap, hand lotion and shampoo. No body wash, no hair conditioner. I get more when I stay at a Marriott hotel. C'mon Rio! Also the walls are paper thin. I could hear everything in the rooms next to me.

And then there's Voodoo. TERRIBLE club\/lounge whatever you wanna call it. The crowd was much older than we expected. The service was mediocre and the music was sub par. Not to mention they pulled the fire alarm TWICE to clear the dance floor. What a waste of money. Now this does not include the host Brandon. He was excellent. 

Pay an extra $50 and go to any other hotel near the strip.

I have stayed many times at the Rio but won't anymore.  Don't leave anything in your room that you wish to take home with you.  Once I notified them of the 3 stolen items they went into defense mode, never said they were sorry told me to call the police.  I checked out immediately.  Aloha Rio

Me and my boyfriend come to Vegas maybe twice a year, and everytime we stay at a different hotel. This time we stayed at Rio and I LOOOOOOVE this place!!! We got here around 3AM and the computers were down. Usually I get inpatient, but at 3am I'm exhausted, and there was no line, so whatever I just dealt with it. So we get checked in, and turns out our room is alllll the way at the end of the hall. Finally, we get to our room and WOW is all I can say.

Because we were at the end, we got both the mountain view and strip view! Very nice to see at night! Room is very big, big bathroom with 2 sinks.

The only thing is that our room never got cleaned. So knocked off a star for that.

During our stay, we went to VooDoo Restaurant and Lounge, and the food at the Restaurant is very good. The lounge is 51 floors up, and when you get there, you can see all of Vegas!! Good atmosphere, everyone there having a good time.

Love this place!! Had a great time!

be aware of $8 room service charge... see receipt
1 cheesecake 1 chocolate decadent , 1 glass milk from room service menu... Room service was extremely friendly... desserts weren't bad... but price gouging kills experience ... Don't do "Gotchas" RIO.... 

Bathroom shower not all that either

Have stayed at this property before and have not been there for a couple of years. 

The rooms are run down and urgently need updating. The carpet was soiled and the bathroom is now dated. There was a definite odor that was not pleasant. Also, there is no in-room coffee service anymore even with the outrageous mandatory $32 (with "tax") resort fees (unless you are a upgraded player). This "resort fee" was not in place on my last visits. They claim it is for "basic" internet service and use of the exercise facility but feels like a way to get for revenue. Really a rip-off if you don't use those services. This type of gouging does not make for good customer relations. 

The room was not ready as was promised, and even though I had on-line check in, had to stand in a line for about 30 minutes.

Given the final cost, we could have done better and will not be back. Just not the Rio we remember sadly. Not a pleasant experience at all.

BORING. We always stayed on the strip and visited the Rio in the evening. Enjoyed the gondolas in the sky along with the little stage show that they put on. This was the 1st time we actually stated at the Rio. Unfortunately, both shows have been eliminated. Even though we had out car, we took the shuttle to the strip. No fun waiting in 112 temperature for a shuttle. Too much of a hassle.  NO reason to go there.

I had never been to Vegas before, and after reading very mixed reviews on the Rio on here I had low expectations and was ready to assume the worst. 

We arrived about 2:30-3pm, parked on the 3rd floor of the parking garage and walked through the tower to check in, a cool walk since you see a ton of what they offer in the Rio. We had to wait in line for about 10 or so minutes to check-in, no biggie. We had a very nice woman check my husband and myself in (we are in mid\/late 20s). The world series of poker is going on there so there isn't a ton of availability but she did give us a few options--prior to arriving we requested the Ipanema tower and non smoking (those have been more recently updated). We went up to our room and were very pleasantly surprised. 

It was super clean, and a good size room. We checked our bed- no bed bugs, clean sheets, etc. Our bathroom was clean and amenities were provided. We were on the 5th floor and had an okay view, it was neat at night with the lights but you don't spend much time in your room so it doesn't matter if you have a super high floor too much. The coffee in the room does cost $ but we just ended up grabbing Starbucks downstairs each morning. 

A few tips and misconceptions I had prior to Vegas:
-They make everything cheap so you spend more on gambling. WRONG!
Everything is super expensive. Yes you can get a good deal on your room, but set aside more money than you think for food. The only time food is cheap is some of the breakfast buffets, but even lunch or dinner buffets are very expensive! Water bottles are super pricey too so bring some of your own water bottles and stick them in the second fridge in the bathroom area.

-If you even lift anything from the stocked mini bar, they will automatically charge you due to a weight sensor. We had to get a few things taken off but they were very nice about it. So remember there is a second fridge if you want to store things, but, don't lift anything in the mini bar unless you are buying something. 

-Play penny slots and get free drinks, tip the waitress a dollar. My husband and I weren't planning on gambling that much but we knew we would be drinking. Once we realized basic drinks were $9 and specialty were $12-$15, we quickly caught on that even if you are playing penny slots you get free drinks. So try your luck gambling and spend as much as you would on drinks. Or buy your own alcohol and take some shots in the room before you walk around.

-Across the street from the Rio there is a place called "Golden Casino". You can sit at the bar and play 0.25cents Blackjack and get free drinks even faster than at the Rio. You are always waiting for a server to walk by but at the Golden, the bartender is right there and you can get free drinks back to back to back. Also, it is way less smoky than the Rio- which gets pretty thick and we had to take breaks out of it.

-The pool at the rio is free for girls and guys. Only the back pool which is the topless one costs for guys- so, anyone who wrote it is $20 for guys---that's only one of their 3 huge pools. 

-We had the $6.99 golden casino breakfast buffet and it was decent, served its purpose. 

-The free shuttle from the rio to the strip is easy, comes frequently and so it's not a big deal to stay off the strip. We ate at the cheesecake factory in Caesar's Palace one night and had a ton of fun with our group there.

-Bellagio Fountains & Gardens are a fun free thing to check out. 

-2 nights is all you need unless you have a ton of money and can pay for expensive shows\/more food\/more gambling. I did wish we could've seen a show or two, that would've added to the experience but overall, we still had a super great time with our friends and family.

My boyfriend and I stayed there for 4 nights in the Masquerade Tower (older one). The room was HUGE compared to what I'd seen in other hotels and it felt like a studio apartment.

The shower looked pretty outdated and the water didn't drain very well... there was a small pool of water. There's a vanity area with an extra sink which is nice if someone's using the bathroom. On the last night of our stay, the water took a lot longer than usual to heat up.

The bed was so-so; it felt more bouncy than comfy. I saw a few holes in the sheets... not very impressive.

After a long day of activities we decided to order room service because we didn't want to go around and look for food, but we were told that it would be an HOUR wait... so we went to the All-American Cafe. The service was horrible. Our waitress disappeared after she brought out our food. Our water never got refilled... when she finally returned, we had to ask for more water. When she came back to fill our glasses, it took forever for her to come back again with our check. Meanwhile, there were at least 3 other groups of people who came and went... Too bad we didn't have that waiter.

I liked the Carnival World Buffet. It's supposed to be the largest buffet on the strip, but doesn't seem that big. The food was pretty good considering that most of it had probably been sitting out for a while.

The shuttle to the sister hotels was convenient since Rio is off the strip.

ALL SUMMED UP:: I'd probably go back but request a room in the newer tower.

By far, my stay at Rio was one of the worst hotel experiences I have ever had.

Few things appear to work "right" in this place. For example, the room had a wrong TV control, and when the "good one" was delivered three days later, the Pay Per View Services were disconnected.  It took several hours for a technician to connect the room TV to the Cable Services. 

The Wifi is not consistently works in the room.  The server was not accessible at 12 am, requiring more calls to the technical department.

The electronic keys to the room were "keyed" only for three days, prompting calls for the security and the front desk. If it was a trick by a bellman to get extra tips, or negligence by the reception clerk, I am not certain but it was very unpleasant. 

Moreover, the phone lines do not work. I was be placed on hold, for a several minutes more than ones, just to find myself disconnected. When the phone was answered by the outsourced operator, she said that the lines seem to be down. She told me to call 10 -15 minutes later.

The cleaning crew are slamming doors in the middle of the night, and early in the morning.

On the first day of the arrival, hotel guests were asked to leave the pool area, and it was boarded off, because of a private party.  People protested, but were forced to leave.  It was strange, and inappropriate, as the hotel charges $28 daily for the"resort" fees. Upon the entrance of the spa area, which is the only way to access the gym, a young man, who works the desk, raised his voice demanding to sign his name down, prior permitting to inspect the gym. The tone of his voice was not acceptable, and he attempted to recover his grace by overcompensating with eagerness to help (later). 

I couldn't find coffee in the room. Apparently,  Rio charges fees for coffee pods ($9), which are stored in a mini bar.  Tea is only available through the room services (more tips and fees). The fees are charged pretty much for anything else, which is typically placed in a room ($3.24 to open a wine bottle that we purchased in  a lobby downstairs).  

I hope this is enough for readers to understand how poorly this business is managed. Hotel or service management, if it is present in this place, is not available via the phone, and must be seeing in person on the first floor. 

This is definitely not a 4-star hotel, and people should be aware of all problems that will affect their stay at Rio All-Suites Hotel & Casino.

all suites......WHAT! YEYAH! the rooms are much nicer than they used to be: less miami, more modern. the rooms are giant and the room rates are great.

the only bummer is that it isn't right on the strip, but there's a shuttle that takes you from the rio to harrah's.

we stayed here (all 6 girls including myself) for my last fling before the ring bachelorette party. the rooms are spacious. we had a suite that fit 6 girls. but most of all, i loooooooove their pool area! i would come back and stay here again! just not on a 3 day holiday weekend. it was so crowded! 

the bathrooms were nice and spacious. loved the shower head! ahaha that's always a plus especially when you're from out of town and then, you take a shower and it's pretty much hard water -- i'm very picky when it comes to that. 

we spent some time at their american grill and loved the food!

Stayed here 7\/23 - 7\/26. The check in line was long and I was in it for about 20 minutes with about 20 more to go and a man started picking a few people at a time and took them to the VIP are to check in. He picked my on this second go round, so that was really nice. 
The room was big. Enough for my husband, 2 teenage boys, and 2 under 10. Plenty of room with the 2 queen beds and a pull out sofa. For the price it wasn't bad, spacious, clean room. The pool were nice. More than one and the building provided shade in the afternoon. I requested linens for the sofa and they were brought up in 10 minutes. On our second day I had to return to the room after we had gone downstairs and when I returned, the housekeeper was tending to the room. I said hi and told her I was going to get something. Well, my husband had moved the bag to the closet and when she noticed my attempt to retrieve something quickly had failed and I was walking aimlessly, she nicely asked me to put my key card in the door. I told her no problem and thanked Flor for asking me to do so. That was great that staff are taught to do so and not afraid to ask guests to do this. Equals asking for ID when I use my credit card at the store.  
The down sides: No free internet, no microwave in the room, the fridge wasn't very cold, low shower pressure, and only three bath towels in the room daily (I need more). I had asked the girl who checked me in (in the VIP area) to block the TV of purchases. When we got in the room my 8 yr old turned on the TV and didn't realize he bought Spongebob for $4.The coffee maker in the room is a Keurig. If you have one bring your own K-cups. They are available for purchase in the room, 3 for $8! And there wasn't sugar or creamer, but I guess you could borrow some from Starbucks downstairs!

So disappointed in this place! Wow! 

I booked one of their "newly renovated" rooms for a night and I have to say it was not upto par at all!! Disgusting in fact 

Dirty, dusty, stains on the chairs, water leaks and just old. You cannot add contemporary art in a out dated room and call it renovated? I mean the floor to ceiling windows and size of the suite were nice but thats about it. Everything else was so dirty and old?

Just no love in this place, they have let it go! You're better off booking at La Quinta Inn!

I booked this hotel due to its great price and i must admit that I definitely got more than expected. Its kind of off the strip but they do offer a shuttle that run every 30 minutes until 1 AM. The bed was extremely comfortable (not that you will be in it much in Vegas). Parking was on-site and free. I booked via Expedia and they had a disclaimer about a $200 deposit charge but the deposit was only the standard $50. I will definitely stay here again on my next visit.

Stayed here for one day the Saturday for the Mayweather fight. Check-in was pretty easy I did the early check-in. Early check-in is $20 there is signs that tell you that. it was worth it because I got there at 10:45am and was in the room at 11:05am. Also they put a $200 hold on your card. 

The room is HUGE they are all suites here. It has a pull out couch bed so if anyone needs to crash they can. I can see why folks think the rooms are outdated because they definitely are lol 

But they are clean and comfy so nothing really to worry about unless you're trying to impress someone with a room you will only be sleeping in if you do Vegas right. 

It's about a 20 walk away from the strip. There is a free shuttle that drops you off at either Bally's or Harrah's that runs until 1am. Yes it picks you up from either Bally's or Harrah's too.

Food court? yeah no Please eat before coming back if you get hungry late at night you're basically SOL. 

Overall I enjoyed my stay. Would I stay here again? Probably not just because it's a little further from the strip than I'd like. But that's the only reason.

Rio is a good choice for a stay in LV. It is an all suites hotel so the rooms are rather large. They have good dining options Buzios is great for fish and The Wine Cellar is a good high end restaurant. The show the Carnival in the sky is one of those fun, campy Vegas things and you don't have to stop gambling since it happens overhead in the casino. The casino is part of the Harrahs chain so your points there help with the comps. The hotel is a few blocks off the strip but there is a shuttle up to the Harrahs.

It's a super nice hotel! Rooms were nice, and had a lot of things like q-tips, shaving stuff, hair cap, toothbrush, and so much more. But they messed up and went to such harsh measures saying they were going to call security on their mistake like okay... Not good for kids at call not one kid thing to do
Fun as always. Disappointed there was no masquerade in the sky. Not sure if we missed it or perhaps none today. Oh well the food is still good.

The Rio should change its name to The Favela. If you don't know what that is, go to Wikipedia and look it up. 

We were there for what was supposed to be a special occasion. This is definitely not my first foray into a casino. I've been to Vegas plenty of times, almost exclusively to Harrah's properties. My mother, a Diamond Club Total Rewards Member, arranged our stay as a gift for us through her casino host at Caesar's in Atlantic City, sight unseen. The Paris hotel was full that weekend, but we were assured that the Rio was just as faaaaabulous. If you're an Atlantic City person, you'll understand this reference: The Rio is about as fabulous as The Claridge.

Valet: We arrived at 11 p.m. on a Thursday to a check in situation that left us sitting in our motionless vehicle for a good 45 minutes before we decided to take it upon ourselves to move our luggage ourselves. When one of the valets saw us "stealing" a luggage cart, he decided to stop talking to girls in the taxi stand line and help us the other 2 feet inside. 

Check In: Worse than Thanksgiving weekend airport security, ruder than TSA. We waited in the longest line I have ever seen at any casino check in. Naturally, we were overjoyed when our room turned out to be on the lucky 13th floor. REALLY...they have a 13th floor...in Las Vegas. We brushed it off until we got inside because again, our "suite" was supposedly fabulous. Maybe 19 years ago it was fabulous, but not anymore.

Room #1: All I wanted to do when we arrived was take a bath, get a bite to eat, and go to bed. Our room was not the most modern, but we could deal with that. I'd still have to say the least appealing aspect of our room was the creepy, peep show window into the bathroom. Seriously, who wants to watch their suite-mate sit on the toilet?  The fact that the room was not clean was a deal breaker. Idea #1 was nixed as soon as I saw our filthy bathtub. The previous guest must have been a coal miner with the black ring around the inside of the tub. Then we noticed the broken light bulbs still in the sockets around the mirror and the broken doorbell. I was looking at the carpet and said out loud 'Ohhh I should vacuum.' before I caught myself and thought 'Vacuum?! I'm in a hotel!' When I called to request a change of room, the broken phone cord actually fell out of the phone. We finally got through to the front desk manager  who told us to tell the bellman that we were moving to a room on the 29th floor when he arrived with our luggage. The bellman would let us in, then someone would be up to the new room with a key shortly. 

Room #2: The new room was cleaner and a little more modern, but still with the creepy peep-show window onto the toilet. We waited 45 minutes for our new key to arrive before we decided to call the front desk again about the key because we were starving and it was now almost 2 a.m. Besides, if a key card takes almost an hour, how long would it be before we saw room service? We ventured down the the bloody awful and messy Whopper Bar, our only option, and ate our food amidst some low rent prostitutes resting their feet and catching naps.

Back to the front desk again, it's now 3 a.m. and the line is even longer than when we arrived. I ended up walking up to the side of the counter and asking to speak with a manager. The clerk refuses to let me speak with the manager and then calls up a guest while I'm standing there who yells at me for getting in front of him on the line. The clerk actually goes to get the manager when I yelled back. Manager shows up with 2 keys for our now second room. Total time for check in: 4 hours. Another 20 minute wait for the elevator and we are finally in our room and in bed. 

We stayed a total of 2 nights, and with the exception of sleeping, spent as little time as possible in The Rio. We hit the buffet once because a friend of ours said that it was awesome when she lived in Vegas 5 years ago. It so wasn't. We didn't bother to drop a dime in the casino either. Any time in casinos or restaurants was spent at other Harrah's properties over on the strip. The Rio (or The Favela) sure left a bad taste in our mouths, and it wasn't just that Whopper.

The hotel rooms are big and spacious although the classic suite decor was a bit dated. There were some small things with the room that could use a little attention, however the room was clean and comfortable. The staff was friendly and on point. From the check in, beverage service, restaurants and gaming staff and bell desk, made for a great experience. It is a little off the strip, but a free shuttle will take you to Harrahs or Ballys.

I would give them -1 if it's possible! Upon entering the room, a very awful smell hit us. The room didn't even look like the pictures on their website. We tried complaining about it and the best they could do was to give us a different room with the same decor saying the picture on the website hasn't been updated. If we want a room like that, it would be $75 more. Wtf?!?!? So our best option was to move to a different room with the same interior look. And guess what? It smelled even worse!!!!! Please do you research and find another hotel. Staying here soured my mood when I should be enjoying Vegas life.

Had an awful night at the RIO, the noisiest hotel I have stayed in Vegas so far! All the strip facing rooms are smoking so to be punished us non smokers have the back hotel rooms with views of the noisy air conditioning units. Even on the 11th floor there is a constant loud noise all night long.

To make things worse staff are throwing glass bottles into the trash all night long with the trash men coming at 1am this morning. Other lorries arriving all morning.

Walls are paper thin so you hear everything. My carpet was also wet with a damp smell but only realised when we arrived at midnight and was too much hassle to move .

Real pity as this hotel has great sized suites and a free shuttle to the strip. But due to the noise factor I would not recommend staying here. Suggest staying East of the strip at the Westin or Hard Rock which is a similar price if you bid on Priceline.

During a recent Vegas trip for Christmas\/birthday celebrations, my husband and I stayed here with my in-laws. My in-laws chose this particular hotel because they have stayed here previously and wanted to go to the Rock of Ages show - which was playing here. We stayed three days and two nights during the week a few days prior to Christmas. (Side note: I would not recommend staying so close to Christmas because a lot of places were closed for the holidays.) Upon arrival, we drove around trying to find a place to park and check in. There was parking but it was on the opposite side of the check in area. So, we parked, then had to walk across the entire hotel before finding the check in. During this walk, many hotel workers stopped us trying to get us to gamble or upgrade or whatever. Finally, after checking in, we had to walk back to the car, drive all the way around to the parking for our specific room area (there are two areas for parking because there are two different towers for rooms). We parked, then had to wander through the hotel again before finding the elevators to our rooms. (Note: During our stay, the elevators went out of service so we had to use the escalators. Then the escalators went out of service, so we had to use the previously not-working elevators. Not sure what was going on, but it became confusing.) The rooms were fine - nothing fancy. They smelled funky - like cigarettes and mouthwash. Overall, it was okay. The location is off the strip but they do have shuttles to the strip (to other hotels owned by whoever owns The Rio). Not sure if I'd come back, as there are much nicer places to stay while in Vegas, but it got the job done during this particular trip.

I don't write complaint reviews but my experience at the Rio over the weekend definitely warrants one. I was a huge fan of the Rio - until they double booked the room I was ALREADY in. 

It is NOT OKAY to have a strange man walk into your hotel room at 11pm at night, especially when you're a woman. THANKFULLY my husband was there and not downstairs at the casino, thankfully the stranger who walked in wasn't drunk, or a creep. Had he been drunk and hardheaded, the situation could have been way worse. Or, had he come a few hours earlier when we were out to dinner, who knows what would've happened to all of our belongings in the room. 

Annoyingly enough, when I called down to the front desk to inform them of what happened, their response was "you're not supposed to be in that room, you're supposed to be in the room next door, we have no one listed in the room you're currently in", trying to make me feel like I had made the mistake. I get it, you're surprised, but the key cards your hotel supervisor  gave us had the room# (the one "I wasn't supposed to be in") written on the envelope they give you with the key cards. Went to the casino, came back - key cards worked. Went to the buffet, came back - key cards worked. I don't get it, if I wasn't supposed to be in that room, why was I in and out of that room for 6 hours before this stranger was booked in the same room? They even made me try my key on that room next door but of course it didn't work. THEN they had the audacity to ask me if I could pack up all my stuff and move to the room that "I'm supposed to be in according to their system". Seriously? You guys messed up and want to inconvenience me EVEN MORE? 

Oh, and I just read on Twitter that a guest was burglarized in their room whle sleeping, the police report read that there was no forced entry... starting to believe this situation wasn't an accident or mistake at all. 

What a horrible and scary experience. I do not recommend the Rio Hotel.

I have stayed here twice. The rooms are a great size and very clean. I like the casino and highly recommend seeing the Chippendales here. My only complaint was the pool with the multi colored tile was pretty darn gross. Tiles are missing and I actually saw a lady cut her foot on the bottom of the pool. The tiles on the side are dirty and the water and a barn yard odor to it. There are two other pools there that could be better.
Seriously? A line of 50+ people to check-in? This place is terrible. I didn't like their spg redemption but that is minor compared to 45 minutes to check in...

I booked and pre paid for 2 rooms for 1 week each. This is currently my last night and I check out tomorrow morning. Everything was great and no complaints with either rooms or with the service. Then on my last night i get a letter tapped to my door saying that previous guests who stayed here had come down with legionnairs disease and the water had been tested and was found to contain legionella bacteria. Why didn't they say anything before taking $2000. For prepaid reservations. What kind of practice is it to tell people after they stay here that they may get sick. So wrong

I just had a really nice stay here. Yes I agree that the place is starting to age and look a bit outdated compared to all the new stuff on the strip. My room or "suite", was pretty standard for a Vegas room. Not really sure what made it a suite, but for $50 hard to complain. Back in the day the Carnival buffet was the best in town, now very average if that. My positive review however is all about the people here. The front desk lady who checked me in was very pleasant. The waitresses, card dealers, floor bosses, and bartenders here are very personable and fun. Even the other players at the tables make this place a fun spot to stay and play at. All very friendly and social. Drinks are stiff and easy to get everywhere. Lots of gaming choices and space to move around although their slot machines were pretty tight. Low table limits too which is nice. Another great thing is that the place doesn't reek of cigarette smoke like a lot of other places. I would certainly come back to the Rio on my next Vegas trip.

Very unhappy with the service. The hotel was clean & nice. But the staff were extremely rude and u willing to help. I felt like the staff talked down to us a lot and were unprepared when booking us in after our Groupon included extra goodies.  Even checking out velemera I believe was her name was EXTREMELY rude and inconsiderate. I think the Rio staff needs to understand that us guests are the ones that decide to check in that pays their bills. Next time I hope your staff will treat other quests better then how we were.

This was my first time stay at the Rio, so here's the breakdown. 

Staff: 5\/5
Friendly & polite.

Room: 3.5\/5
It was a conjoined room (suite), and I had the room with the king-sized bed all to myself. The room includes a sectional sofa, tube t.v., a Jack & Jill sink, & a typical shower\/bathroom. The reason why I gave it a 3.5, is because the pictures from the t.v. fluctuated between black and white, and then to color.  And the floors needed to be vacuumed, or at least underneath the bed.

Bed: 5\/5
So COMFORTABLE.  Not too stiff or too soft, just the right amount of firmness to give you support, yet cradles the body.

Extras: 5\/5
I love that they give you a mini fridge, that kept my water and left-overs nicely chilled.  There's also an ironing board and iron; good for last minute presses.  Hairdrier (standard), and a single cup coffee maker (coffee is, of course comes with a fee).

Noise level: 4\/5
Walls are pretty insulated, however, loud conversations can be heard, though. But overall, outside noise was kept close to none.

we went to rio and stayed there in march the hotels were a good size and fairly clean and a very good price. their seafood buffet was great ! the problem was the valet put a good size smudge on the bumper of the car .it took the valet a while to bring the car up . we did not make a big deal about it at the time seeing that it was a rental and we bought full coverage for the car. it had one of those rear view screens . maybe that was what confused the valet so be careful if you valet there.
There was nothing interesting about this hotel. I wasted 1.5 hours to wait for the show. WARNING: Do not let your kids to watch the FREE show that at RIO hotel. It is intended for adult only.

Rio Hotel Las Vegas looks like your typical nice hotel resort in Las Vegas, but it's not. At the lobby are well dressed Wyndham sales people that will promise you a great time in Vegas if you pay them $80 cash for package of entertainment which includes shows of your choice, fine dining and a free breakfast\/lunch if you will attend a sales pitch meeting for about 1 hour and 20 minutes. No obligation or commitment was expected of attendees, and at the end of the presentation we would get our gifts that we paid $80 in cash for. 

To make a long story short. Food at presentation was lousy at best. We wasted half a day on the presentation. The presentation lasted until 3PM, we almost missed our show since we also were given incorrect shuttle information by the Wyndham sales staff in the Rio Hotel lobby. There is little, if any, communications between Rio management and Wyndham sales staff.

Usually stay here for a powerlifting tournament...but no more.  Paying almost $160 for a "discounted" room? 

Went to check out and found they added extra fees for "making a reservation".  They charged us every day for it, after calling them out on it they removed it on every day but 1.  $32 a night for resort fees? Really? No coffee maker AND Internet was REALLY slow. 

Sorry Rio....you need to update this hotel

I booked a 1600 sq Masquerade Tower Suite, to throw a surprise birthday party for my wife. While checking in I told the agent that we only be at the room a very short time 4 hrs or less and want to pay the $200 cash for the security deposit.  I told her I hate waiting 5 to 7 days to have my deposit returned to my credit card deposit so I rather pay cash. She told me that she needed a card on file but will not charge it.  I told her no it's on file from the reservation.  She gave me her word that she would not charge the card but needed to put it in the system. I gave her the card and $200 in cash, about 4 hrs later I checked out the hotel and received my $200 back minus the unfair resort fee and other fake changes they force on you.

The next day, I check my account and discovered she did put a $200 hold on my card even after giving her the $200 in cash. It was very disappointing, but now I have no access to that money for 5 to 7 days. 

As for as the hotel and room goes, I was very, very disappointed. I'd like to think if you're booking a 1600sq room it would have more than your average room. Guess again. Internet cost over $13 a day, to listen to music through the TV cost over $13 a day...I get free internet in lesser name hotels and free music on channels through their TV.  The suite itself was very nice but again, it had a lot of little things wrong inside. List include but not limited to; Broken shower, Adjusting the room temp, Dirty floors, and must of all the view. We had to keep the curtains close because there was to SUPER BRIGHT LIGHT coming in from the parking garage. - So much from enjoying the wonderful view of the strip. I would have been better off going with 2 a joining rooms instead of wasting over $350 for a not so great suite.

Total Fees
$350 for the suite
+ Resort Fee
+ Proc Fee
+ Taxes
+ etc, etc,

Thank god, I didn't use the internet, or need the to music for the party.
The Rio is simply an over priced average hotel, who's trying to squeeze every
penny out of you.

When I call the hotel to discuss these issues, it seem they could care less. No offers for discount for a future stay, no waiving of any fees or even a free buffet. As a local I never go to the strip but if I ever need a room again, it will not be at the Rio.

My main problems with the Rio were: the garbage floating in the pools (bottles, cups, straws, etc.) during the daytime, while staff goofed around and flirted with each other instead of cleaning, the extreme long distance you often had to walk with luggage to get from an elevator to a room, the underbaked potatoes delivered by room service, the overpowering ozone used to filter out smoke (gave 5 of us nosebleeds), and the horrible restaurants in the casino (my husband ordered a crown and coke, and got cheap whiskey in Pepsi, I ordered French fries and they came with no salt)... That being said, I have stayed in worse places. The staff were friendly, the rooms large, there were safes and refrigerators available, the beds were not too bad, and the Rio was a $10 cab ride from the strip.

I go to Vegas often and try to stay at (and review) a different hotel each time I go. So far I've stayed at the Excalibur (ick!), Monte Carlo, Luxor (tower rooms ONLY), Flamingo (GO rooms are AWESOME!!), and now the Rio. Part of my stay was comped (3 out of the 4 nights we stayed) but that doesn't sway my opinion of the place. Yes, the rooms are BIG. Beds are oh so comfortable. The pillows are lacking but I've had worse. You get 2 fridges in the room (one's a mini-bar but the other is empty for your own stuff). We liked the bathroom. Spacious for 2 people to get ready at one time. The shower\/tub combo is average. Tub isn't large enough for the average adult to bathe in (typical). The shower had great water pressure and there was ample space to put  your shower necessities which was nice - no fumbling. View was of partial-strip - what I expected. Rooms could use an update. The bench at the end of the bed was a bit crusty - they really need to get rid of these. Having the extra seating in the room (sofa, chair, desk with 2 upright chairs were nice and allowed us to hang in the room at times without feeling cramped). 

This hotel is not on the strip. No airport\/hotel shuttle, which they SHOULD have since they are not a Strip hotel. Cab fare was reasonable from the airport - $25 to get there and around $18 back (I believe there was traffic on the way there). We did use the free hotel shuttle to their strip properties (Ballys and Harrahs) and took a cab back to the hotel (this was because we didn't want to wait in the heat of August for them). The cab back to the hotel ran about $10-$15 (depending where we left from). 

The casino is okay. We didn't "win" but we did play a LONG time on what we did put in. We didn't fare any better at any of the strip casinos either. Cocktail service at the Rio was AWESOME. We never had any problems or a long wait any of the 4 nights we were there. Yes, the entertainment (show in the sky, the servers who dance\/sing) is WAY lame. Felt we were at the America's Got (some) Talent Casino. They really need to stop with the singing and dancing. No one stops and watches it except for the pervy men who gawk at  the dancers and then don't tip them when they're finished. I just don't see the point of this. 

I do have A LOT to say about the food during our stay, but those are separate reviews.

Overall, I like the Rio. I will stay again but only if they give me a good deal (future comp?). I'd rather stay on the strip and have the convenience of other restaurants and the option to run to Walgreens for cheap soda and snacks (Rio wanted $3.95!! for a single soda in their store). And, I would be sure to bring my own pillow and pay for an upgraded room with a Jacuzzi.

I remember when the RIO used to ROCK harder than any other hotel casino in town, but this way waaayyyy back in the late 90's.  It's sad to see what was such a grand dame age so poorly.

Rooms are large but completely outdated without flatscreens.  Carpet, drapes and bathrooms are in desperate need of updating, and I saw many worn out and taped spots on casino floor.  Harrah's bought and paid a fortune for this property and are obviously trying to milk every single cent out of it.  It's sad, and only stayed here on NYE because I waited too long to book at the places I normally stay at like ARIA and the Wynn.  Restaurants weren't great back in the 90's and still aren't very good, although the burger I had at the American Grill was really tasty.  No good looking people stay here and the cheese factor has definitely been turned up with bikini clad chicks singing karaoke on top of the slot machines.

Definitely wouldn't be coming back here!

Old rooms.   My buddy had a big suite .   I thought I was in a Brady Bunch episode.   Bring out the black lights and let really see whats on the old ass couches. haha  The Valet was friendly.   Save the money and stay at hooters for half the price.

Ist what a shock to find that they TOOK OUT all of the coffee pots in the rooms so mornings are a long trek to Starbucks.  It has one of the smallest casinos for such a large Property.  Bad variety of games.  Rooms are old and dirty, caulking in shower\/tub is missing or badly applied. The tissue holder is falling off the wall.  Besides being close if you are playing in a WSOP event, this casino is not impressive.  There are many more that are beautiful and closer to the main Las Vegas strip.  I'll go back to Tahoe before coming back to this overly crowded Las Vegas city. Traffic is at a stand still way too much.

Great price for a suite which includes bed and sitting area, a couch and a very large vanity that most ladies will love! The room itself was great! Very spacious. Perhaps the furniture is a little old or scuffed here and there but definitely not a deal breaker.

My only complaint with the room we had was that the plumbing was very old. When you washed your hands in the bathroom sink, it would make some weird back up noise in the vanity sink outside the bathroom. Again, not really a deal breaker, just annoying. And please management, please update your shower heads!!! They are so dated and old and don't even spray properly. Living with that for 4 nights made me come home and analyze my own shower situation. Hub and I replaced our own shower head the next day.
:  )

It's not as exciting as the hotels on the strip but it does the job. There are a  few restaurants and a Starbucks even. And the main gift shop seems to be open 24 hours but not positive on that. It's great for your morning Tylenol or to get a quick snack. 

I think I would come back to this hotel. It was a great deal and didn't make me feel dirty.

37\/night for the penthouse suite in the Ipanema Tower? 5 Stars!!

Yes, I can be bribed for 5 stars. This place ROCKS. So we needed an extra night in Vegas, since my buddy's flight wasn't leaving until Monday night. I phoned up some contacts, pulled some strings, and found Imperial Hotel for 17\/night and Rio for 37\/night (Mountain View, King Bed). I'm more of a Planet Hollywood guy, but for 110\/night no thanks. I ended up going with the Rio, even though it was off the strip. 

The whole time I was thinking... old hotel, the room is going to be gross... it's going to be so gross... what is my friend going to think of me? But to my surprise, the lady at the counter said she was going to give us a complimentary upgrade. When she said upgrade, I thought she was going to give us the strip view. 

She put us up on the 20th floor, where you need a key to operate the elevator. The floor opened up to a really classy, and renovated floor. You know this place is fancy, because there was a concierge desk and a library\/study area. As we walked toward our room, I was cursing that it was at the very end of the hall. We arrived at our room, with a set of double doors. We opened the door and "OH S-!!"

The suite had an large living\/dining area with a powder room with a wet bar. The curtains were operated via electric controls and we had a view of the strip and the pool area. There were two large LCD TVs; one in the living room and one in the master bedroom. The bathroom had a really high tech Jacuzzi. I was so excited that I was literally running around the room with a boner. 

Thanks for the upgrade Rio!

A little about my credentials:
I'm just an average Joe that travels a lot for business and pleasure. I'm an Elite Premier for United, Gold Member for Marriott, and Gold Member for Hilton. I usually book rooms around 130-160\/night depending on location, amenities, and the year the hotel was built\/renovated. My hotel turn offs include: Valet only parking, dirty bathrooms, and paper thin walls.

Got here at 12 went to the room and saw stuff from the last guest in the refrigerator and the bathroom was dirty we switched rooms
We got back to our room at around 10 PM our room supposed to be smoke-free but next room to us was smoking pot and playing hip hop music very loud 
I don't smoke and the pot smell was all over my room so I called the manager and asked him after they fix the issue to call me she said I'm not going to call you back but I will tell the security to call you back
To me that's very unprofessional of a casino manager plus the security never called me on the continued smoking pot all night and since the hotel was booked they could not put me into another room
Traveling on vacation or business is all about experience
Well I stay here ever again probably not

Excellent Value! 
Pretty decent, Spacious & Comfortable Suite Room to Stay for the Price you pay.

Spectacular Views from 51st fl Voodoo Lounge, Kind, Helpful Staff,
Great Live band, Great Chippendale show, Delicious Pho and other Asian noodles,
Huge, Nice Convention Areas, Nice Pool, Free shuttle Bus leaves every 30min to Strip 
till 10pm, $28 Resort Fee. There is also a City Bus stop right in front of hotel if you want to travel west side.
I was the one who complained about $175 of my deposit have not refunded but 
It returned back to my bank 3 days later. Lol

Greatly enjoyed myself staying here I highly recommend RIO to anyone or any group visiting Vegas.

Unauthorized Credit Card Charges "Resort Fee" 

The Federal Trade Commission and the Better Business Bureau are starting to receive more complaints about these deceptive business practices. If we continue to complain they will put an end to these "drip pricing" practices.
Copy and paste my sample letter below and complain. It's easy, you can do it online.

"I booked a two night stay at the Rio All-Suites Hotel & Casino, 3700 W. Flamingo Road, Las Vegas Nevada, 89103, telephone number 866-746-7671 ("Rio").  The total cost was $233.52 ($104.25\/night) that included tax and fees. 
Upon check out I was charged an additional $50.00 on my credit card without my authorization.  The clerk at the Rio told me it was a "resort Fee".  I didn't learn about the additional fees until I checked out at the hotel, after I made an online reservation for what I thought was the full price.
When I booked the hotel room online (through Expedia), I expect that the rate I saw was the rate I would pay.  My printed receipt said "Paid in full".  I did not agree to pay additional fees upon check out.
Knowing about extra fees lets me compare rates for different hotels fairly. Had I known about the additional hidden charges up front, I would not have booked this hotel.  By providing a deceptively low estimate of what I could expect to pay for their hotel room, I booked the Rio and it turned out to be much more expensive. These are unauthorized credit card charges.
I feel this is unfair business practice and needs to be addressed and stopped.
Thank you."

Almost every person at the check out desk was complaining about the same thing. The resort fee did not even include internet or coffee. Business count on people being too busy to do anything about it. I hope this helps.

First impression when we walked in the door...everybody said in unison "What the hell is that smell!" 
Smelled like Sh!t. Seriously..  Good thing our friend had room deodorizer in her possession, which we're still wondering why. 
The room was large which was expected because all their rooms were suites. It's a lil difficult for me to not be biased from what I've been used to. I'm a regular at the Wynn, Encore and Palazzo but we got this room Comped so we took advantage of it and accepted it as...well.... Comped. The wall decors looked like they've been renovated but most everything else was out dated. The couch, carpet and drapery were typical 90's. The restroom was very basic. Nothing to brag about. There's no luxurious feel whatsoever but then again, it's not the theme. The plumbing for the two sinks need some work. I can hear the gurgling every time one of them is used. Wifi was not complementary and the TV channels were very limited. The outlets were broken. I mean the wall socket plastic cover was shattered revealing the inner walls and the actual socket was loose. When I tried to plug my phone charger to it, it turned off the alarm clock. Yes there's a short. Isn't this a fire hazard? 
The beds were comfortable. The linens were clean. Loss my butt off on Blackjack but that has nothing to do with the room. Had a great weekend nonetheless.

oh forgot... It's a No Smoking floor but the entire freaking hallway was reeking of Cigarette Smoke. WTF? When we opened the door to go out, it's as if somebody was smoking outside and blowing it directly towards our door for us to take a huge whiff of. We even laughed about it. We get Cig smoke going out and Sh!t smell coming in.

I used to stay here every time I visited Vegas, about once a year.  Recently I discovered that one of their employees, a card dealer named Shawn Grissom celebrated the death of a recent police officer and added that there should be more dead police officers. We contacted Rio and they refused to do anything except put out a canned response but decided NOT to discipline the employee.  So now I and 30K of my brothers and sisters in blue will actively boycott your establishment.  

If you work in Law Enforcement or have a family member or loved one that works in Law Enforcement, please forward this information to others.

Comped stay through TR. Room is definitely dated, and looks like it has not been updated since the 90's. Shower pressure barely enough to remove soap and shampoo...Use of the spa facilities is free if you are Diamond or above, and the spa is pretty nice. Not canyon ranch nice, but ok for the Rio.
Ate at El burro restaurant and it was ok, nothing memorable or special about the meal except the price! $25 for a small single portion of nachos and a soda!! Wtf?
Valet was great about charging the car nightly, which was appreciated. Housekeeping good as well. Spent more time at other properties like Cosmo and Wynn as there is just not much happening here.

YUCK! 

I stayed here this past week for a conference (along with several other colleagues) and it definitely ruined my Vegas experience.

I stayed one night at the MGM grand before I arrived, and as soon as I took a cab across the highway away from the strip ($8 to cross a highway??-that's another topic) I had a bad feeling about the place. 

Upon entering the room, I had the reflexive instinct to pick up the phone and call the front desk to see what the cost would be to cancel my reservations. $50. In retrospect, a small price that I should have paid, but didn't unfortunately.

The reason I came to the Rio (aside from being onsite for the conference) was because I was really excited to go swimming. The pools were promoted on the website as being fabulous, so that sold me. When I got there, the pools had been closed for the winter. Argh. When we asked the front desk manager about the swimming elsewhere in the 'city' he told us we could get into the Paris or Caesar's pool at no charge. Wish they would have told us that sooner. 

Anyway--I like to be concise, so I'll wrap it up. I'm just going to list off some of the 'highlights'---
vomit in the casino not cleaned up, banged up furniture and the worst bed & bed clothes I've ever seen in a hotel, a shower faucet that sprayed water over the top of the shower curtain and onto the bathroom floor at random, late night patrons of the bar taking it upon themselves to provide their own version of a peep show, tiny and crowded gym that I used for $22, off the strip location, and the list goes on and on.

I wish I would have checked out and stayed elsewhere.. there is no way that this place should have cost $175 a night. I could have stayed at the MGM grand for that price-- which, in comparison to Rio is the lap of luxury.

I'll leave you with this Rio Tag Line. The interpretation is up to you. 

The Rio: "Exotic, Uninhibited. Fun.'

Whenever in Vegas we somehow end up spending a lot of unexpected time hanging around the Rio, which is pretty random considering that we always stay on the strip. During our most recent trip we went to a couple of shows here and in previous trips we visited their seafood buffet. They are currently running The Eddie Griffin Experience and Penn & Teller. Rio, unlike some of the neighboring hotels, draws a larger crowd from the strip for its food and entertainment. 

They have an all you can eat seafood buffet that we tried last year on my husband's birthday. The buffet was good and perhaps even worth the $50 pp price tag. We played a few slots here, but didn't win anything. We mainly hang out here usually waiting for a show or food, which means that Rio is doing something right to draw in the crowds. As for the decor, they have a festival, Mardi Gras thing going on here. The casino clearly hasn't been remodeled in recent years and looks out of date compared to some of the newer ones on the strip. What it does provide is a relaxed atmosphere. It also has some cheap gift shops and a Burger King located in the main atrium. I would not advise making a special trip here without plans as there is not much to see. If you like seafood or any of the entertainment options, it's not a bad property to hang out at in the meantime.

I stayed at the Rio for the first and last time ever this past week. I really liked the rooms  as they were  clean, large and had a separate a vanity area. The rooms come with a refrigerator but no coffee maker. I wasn't too impressed with the bedding. The pillows were horrible and there were really no blankets on the bed only sheets.

My only real complaint  comes from an unfortunate circumstances these past two days. On Wednesday night we were detained out of our room on the 21st floor due to a small fire on floor above. Now I understand the hotel can't foresee these circumstances and thank God everyone was okay, but their mode of communication was ineffective. Anytime we asked the staff members for information, they were rude and unhelpful. But later on we were allowed to go back up to our room and all was well. However at 6 a.m. the next morning the fire alarm went off on our floor (21st floor) followed by an announcement on the speakers that everything was okay and not to be alarmed. My boyfriend and I decided to open the door to see what was going on in the hallway and the 21st floor was completely full of smoke. Scary feeling, so we decided to take the stairwell down 21 floors and evacuate. They didn't evacuate the 21st floor until later.  We were kept out of our rooms from 6am till 4pm.  Anytime we asked questions we couldn't get answers. They had such a poor emergency response to a reported electrical malfunction on the 21st floor. They put us in the showroom with water, but we never really got any answers from them letting us know what happened and what was going on. About 2:30 p.m. they told us they were relocating guests to a different hotel and get in line for the letter at registration. The line at registration took over an hour, then we were escorted back up to our room on the 21st floor via the stairwell to pack all our stuff and carry all our stuff down 21 floors again. Again, I understand the hotel has no control of what had happened. My major complaint was how poorly they handled this crisis. They had no systems in place to work with the guests. We kept asking and getting conflicting answers. Being pulled out of bed at 6 a.m. with just the clothes on your back was very scary. We finally got changed to the Flamingo and got back in a new room about 5:30 p.m. We had a whole day wasted on Wednesday. Now they did give us free buffet tickets and gave us the last night free.  But Rio really needs to work on customer relations in regards to crisis situations as such. They need to set up a command post where you can get answers from and regular updates on what is going on. Around 9 a.m. several of us heard the fire chief tell the hotel staff that they should start relocating the guests, but for some reason the hotel didn't.  If they would have relocated us then, then we would have recouped some of our day.   I will never stay at the Rio Hotel again, just for the pure fact that I don't feel safe. I know they're an older hotel but they really need to invest in a crisis plan for when something like this happens. It's highly unacceptable to tell people that everything's under control when the entire hallway is filled with smoke (not just a little bit, but completely filled with smoke). I think corporate really needs to come down and look at everything. New systems and procedures need to be put in place effective immediately.  This is just an opinion as a guest.  If they explained  everything, I think they would have had less angry guests.  Communication is key in any crisis situation.
Just spent two nights at the Rio Hotel and Casino and only have ONE COMPLAINT- the POOL CLOSES AT 5PM. Why? The weather is so nice......

GF and I stayed here for a "staycation" as we are locals. I bought a groupon for $25. I honestly did not expect much since it was an off the strip hotel but I ended up being highly impressed.

We got a strip view room, and at night the view of the strip was amazing. Our room was very romantic and sexy. Definitely a baby making atmosphere. 

If you are staying here, I highly recommend Voodoo Steakhouse. It is on par price wise ($50-100 per plate) with other top strip restaurants but did not disappoint.

Stayed here for our wedding weekend, which makes it pretty difficult to write a review. Casino reviews are tough anyway, but it's even more challenging when reviewing a place connected with a life experience.

We stayed in a Masquerade Suite. Those are the large endcap suites in the taller of the two towers. The suite is around 1500sf, and has floor to ceiling windows that wrap around 180 degrees. From the dining area, past the living area, through the bedroom, and all the way to the jacuzzi tub, you get a view that includes both the Strip and the mountains.

The view is to die for, especially on a higher floor.

The furnishings are dated, and pretty worn. You will find frayed edges all over every chair. You will find gouges in the wooden frames of chairs, even some pieces missing. The bed is comfortable, but certainly not top-notch.

Check-in can be annoying, unless you are at least Platinum with Total Rewards (the shared players club with Harrah's, Caesar's, Paris, etc). Platinum status is worth next to nothing in most parts of the country. But it's very useful at the Rio. Skipping the long checkin line is great.

Guest services was friendly. I have no complaints there. But there were the typical number of glitches. 

Overall I would give the place 3.5, but I am rounding down. There just isn't enough "wow" factor for that 4th star. Because while many things at the Rio are awesome (great buffets, great rooftop lounge), those are items I can review separately, and those are items you don't have to be staying here to enjoy. You can stay somewhere else and then visit for a few hours.

3 stars.

I have NEVER had such a horrible experience at a hotel. First strike, I tried to check in with two different front desk employees and they had the worst costumer service they were very rude, smart remarks, and were not helpful at all! they charged me for 3 reservations. I asked two different front desk employees to cancel them, they said it was cancelled. I later speak to a manager and she had to cancel because the reservations were still there. One a good note I was refunded for the 2 reservations. Employees were quick to throw this situation to their manager because they were lazy and did not want to handle the situation. I was unable to check in until I finally spoke to a manager. The rooms were not bad; however the cleanliness of the hotel I rate a 4 on a 10 scale. Game employees didn't have the best customer service, they also seemed rude and unhappy to be working, weren't polite. 

Lastly, it took 1 hour for bell service to finally come up and get my bags. I would not recommend this hotel to anyone unless you're on a serious budget.

Had a good stay at the Rio. The rooms are larger than most hotel rooms which included a couch and a coffee table where you could sit and relax. We had a safe that did not work and a broken luggage rack. The hotel was very busy this particular weekend because of a big fight and College game going on, but all in all it was a good stay.

I'd never stay here again, but I can't say that I had a horrible experience.  I stayed to attend a convention.  The convention space was very nice.

The staff was not helpful inside the hotel during any of my interactions, however the valet was awesome.  I don't feel like I necessarily got a good value for the money and the property itself doesn't have some of the cool factor that places on the strip have.  My biggest complaint is that some of the vendors (the skin care place especially) approached me to sell something every single time I went from the convention space to my room.  That made for a long week.

I enjoyed the restaurants at the casino.  My room was fine.

Don't be discouraged by the age or distance from the strip of this hotel. I've stayed here on two visits to Sin City and played\/eaten here on others and cannot complain. 

They offer a free shuttle that goes between The Rio and strip hotels which runs on a regular basis throughout the day. 

The rooms are good sized and well kept. I've enjoyed staying in both towers. 

The casino and hotel's amenities are all good. The food at the buffets is very good as are the servers and buffet attendants. The casino floor's and breakfast restaurants leave something to be desired in taste and quality of the food. The service in the restaurants is also fair at best. The most disappointing thing I have found staying at the Rio is the short dining hours. After 10:00 pm there is only the restaurant on the casino floor to eat at and I've just commented on that.

My favorite thing about this hotel & casino is the staff. The casino staff and the hotel staff (check-in and housekeeping) are very friendly and professional. I felt most welcomed by the staff here compared to any of the other Las Vegas hotels that I've stayed at.

If you are looking for an unpretentious, good quality, casino hotel for a fair price in Las Vegas the Rio should not disappoint.
I had an awesome vacation at the Rio staff was professional check in was easy highly recommend it
Very dirty room. No entertainment just awful place to be.  KJ Chinese is great though but skip this hotel when you visit vegas

While it's starting to look a little dated, it's still a great place.  The rooms are huge, with floor to ceiling windows, and a fridge you can actually use.  The buffet is still one of my favorites for a champagne brunch (I love the Mongolian station).  Good pool(s).  The wine cellar is awesome.  Voodoo Lounge still has amazing views.  Shuttle service to the strip.  Great venue to hold the WSOP.  

They probably should start pouring some money into sprucing up the place, because it's kinda at the turning point.  If they let it go, it will look like hell in a few more years, but it's at the point where it can still be saved.  I hope they get on it, because I really like the place.

We only stayed there because it was a promotional trip. We will never be back! Run down is an under statement, rooms need updating and repairs the elevators shake and shutter and over charge you for everything. DO NOT STAY THERE!!!!
Robert at the Carnival Buffet is an amazing server. He is very attentive & friendly. Be sure to request him!!

ugh, another disappointment with customer service at the Rio.  The trip before this one, the guy at VIP checkin was very eager to help, gave me the number to call for any assistance, and later that day, I had a letter under my door about how he was happy to help, VIP assistance number, etc, etc..  Anyways, that trip, nothing went wrong so I didn't have to look for that number.  However, this last trip was a disaster.  Yes I did VIP checkin again, but didn't receive a number at the beginning, and the letter came the next day.  Right after check-in, came to the room and the safe was already locked!  The phone in the room took a while to figure out (no front desk or concierge button----you have to push a different button and get transferred or later I found out just push 0).  Took two phone calls and 2-3 hours to get someone to open the safe.


The worst part of the trip was that I was checked out without me knowing!! I tried to use my reward credits\/etc at the host to help cover my bill, but I was already checked out!!!!  The very rude lady at checkout was no help.  I explained that I didn't check out and wanted to know how it was possible that I was already checked-out???  I probably got the worst response... "DO YOU WANT TO CHECK BACK IN???"  I tried to explain it again.....and got the exact same response from her.  After figuring out that she wouldn't be of any help I just left and accepted the full price bill.

The resort fees seem to have gone up as well.  And get this, even if they give you a room offer, you still need to pay them.  Its not like that at most other places.  Just a tip!

I got a in mail promotion for the rio hotel and Cesar's group for a two night stay for free. I booked to the rio hotel since it was the nicest out of the group. I called reservations and they booked me for a normal room, no upgrade for my stay. 

I was wanting a strip view room. If it was available i could pay a upgrade charge for 40 dollars a night. I was in luck, she said there was a samba suite with a strip view room. I decided to upgrade. I go to my room and it was not a strip view room, it was a view of the mountains and freeway. I saw the corner of the strip. Trump to be exact. I was extremely disappointed. I called the front desk and asked to be downgraded. I was on hold for 7 minutes until i got in hold with hotel operations. He said he would lower it to 20 a night.  

Even though i couldn't get the full strip view, i cant beat 40 dollars for two nights. It was before a huge concert and regular rooms were topping 150 a night.

So disappointed in my experience here. My room that I paid 150$ a night for had a broken refrigerator, torn up counter tops , leaky faucets and water taps.i was told they had no other rooms available and would not give me any kind of credit for my problem. I am having to put a wash cloth under the water tap to keep my bathroom countertop drier. Don't waste your money coming here

Checked-in on a Monday night, checked-out on Wednesday afternoon. Came from the most frightening hellhole of a hotel called Tropicana. Paid $55 a night!

Not the most amazing of hotels or casinos, I will say that. You'll find flashier, newer, and more dazzling on the strip, of course. But our room was clean and a welcome respite after the shock of the Tropicana, which I suppose wasn't saying much, so I'll say this: it's a normal, nice-but-not-luxurious hotel room. Decor was fairly modern, if simple. 

We had some difficulties with the front desk: key cards kept screwing up, and the front desk line is always like forever-and-a-day long. But they always brought towels up when we asked (we asked a few times!), and room service was prompt. 

I did have a run-in with one of the valets, when I needed to catch my friends who I had JUST let out of my car. They were headed up to the room and I was going to go park, but had given them the wrong key. I moved my car out of the main overhang area, jumped out, and the valet started shouting bloody-murder about how he needed my keys. I ran inside anyway, gave the room key to my friends, and when I returned to my car about 1.5 mins later, the valet was still standing in front of my car, giving me the evil eye. He then asked "What my problem was." I told him to go park a car or something and left. It was just weird and overbearing. I suppose he deals with Vegas d'bags all the time, but it's not like I left my car there for an hour and a half, right? And considering that I saw the same cache of cars sitting in that area the entire three days I was there, I didn't think it was that big of a deal to jump out for a minute and a half. 

So, if you're looking for a value, I'd say this is a "You get what you pay for, and a little more" scenario. You won't regret your choice, but you're not staying at the Bellagio.

Pros:
-Our room was away from the elevators and mostly quiet. Could hear some doors opening and closing.
-15th floor = cool view of the strip
-Good customer service... I didn't realize there would be a resort fee because we were not told until check out time. I talked to the manager which said it was probably in the terms&conditions when we booked, probably true. Either way he only charged for one of the two resort fees ($20\/$40) so that was nice. 
-Penn&Teller show is located there.
-Affordable prices for rooms.
-Room was pretty large, two queen beds and a sectional couch in there. We also had a mini fridge which was great.
-Close enough to the strip that cabs to get there are cheap.
-Complimentary shuttle to Paris and some other places.

Cons:
-Long check in line... eek!
-Not really walking distance from the strip... if you're wearing heals and care about your safety.
-We went to the Voodoo club on the 51st floor which had a nice view but it wasn't exactly nice... Kind of grungy. 

Overall the casinos and restaurants here were pretty casual and I saw many families there, so I'm guessing its one of the more family friendly hotels.
